text: This document specifies the requirements for the development of a “ Smart House ” , called DigitalHome ( DH ) , by the DigitalHomeOwner Division of HomeOwner Inc . <end>

A “ Smart House ” is a home management system that allows home residents to easily manage their daily lives by providing for a lifestyle that brings together security , environmental and energy management ( temperature , humidity and lighting ) , entertainment , and communications . <end>

The Smart House components consist of household devices ( e . g . , a heating and air conditioning unit , a security system , and small appliances and lighting units , etc . ) , sensors and controllers for the devices , communication links between the components , and a computer system , which will manage the components . <end>
The DigitalHome Software Requirements Specification ( SRS ) is based on the DigitalHome Customer Need Statement . <end>
It is made up of a list of the principal features of the system . <end>

This initial version of DigitalHome will be a limited prototype version , which will be used by HomeOwner management to make business decisions about the future commercial development of DigitalHomeOwner products and services . <end>
Hence , the SRS is not intended as a comprehensive or complete specification of DigitalHome requirements . <end>
There is a supplementary document that provides additional detail and information about the DigitalHome requirements : the Digital Home Use Case Model . <end>
These document were prepared by the DigitalHomeOwner Division , in consultation with the Marketing Division of HomeOwner Inc . <end>
The Digital Home system , for the purposes of this document , is a system that will allow a home user to manage devices that control the environment of a home . <end>
The user communicates through a personal web page on the DigitalHome web server or on a local home server . <end>
The DigitalHome web server communicates , through a home wireless gateway device , with the sensor and controller devices in the home . <end>
The product is based on the Digital Home High Level Requirements Definition . <end>
The Digital Home High Level Requirements Definition is intended as a prototype , which will allow business decisions to be made about future development of a commercial product . <end>

The scope of the project will be limited to the management of devices which control temperature , humidity , security , and power to small appliances and lighting units , through the use of a web - ready device . <end>
The prototype DigitalHome software system will be situated in a simulated environment . <end>
There will be no actual physical home and all sensors and controllers will be simulated . <end>
The general user shall be able to use the DigitalHome system capabilities to monitor and control the environment in his / her home . <end>

The general user is familiar with the layout of his / her home and the location of sensor and control devices ( for temperature , for humidity , and for power to small appliances and lighting units ) . <end>

Although the general user is not familiar with the technical features of the DigitalHome system , he / she is familiar with the use of a web interface and can perform simple web operations ( logging in and logging out , browsing web pages , and submitting information and requests via a web interface ) . <end>
A Master user will be designated , who shall be able to change the configuration of the system . <end>
For example , a Master User shall be able to add a user account or change the default parameter settings . <end>
He / she will have the same right as the DigitalHome Technician . <end>
A DigitalHome Technician is responsible for setting up and maintaining the configuration of a DigitalHome system . <end>
A DigitalHome Technician has experience with the type of hardware , software , and web services associated with a system like the DigitalHome system . <end>
A DigitalHome Technician is specially trained by DigitalHomeOwner to be familiar with the functionality , architecture , and operation of the DigitalHome system product . <end>

A DigitalHome Technician will have rights beyond the DigitalHome General User , capable of setting up and making changes in the configuration of the system ( e . g . , setting system parameters and establishing user accounts ) , and starting and stopping operation of the DigitalHome System . <end>
The “ prototype ” version of the DigitalHome System ( as specified in this document ) must be completed within twelve months of inception . <end>
The development team will consist of five engineers . <end>
DigitalHomeOwner Director will provide management and communication support . <end>
The development team will use the development process specified by the Digital HomeOwner Inc . <end>

Where possible , the DigitalHome project will employ widely used , accepted , and available hardware and software technology and standards , both for product elements and for development tools . <end>
Because of potential market competition for DigitalHome products , the cost of DigitalHome elements ( sensors , controllers , server , tools , etc . ) , for this project should be minimized . <end>

As part of the final project report the development team will describe their efforts to minimize costs , including price comparisons between DigitalHome elements and comparable / competitive elements . <end>
The DigitalHome system will be tested in a simulated environment . <end>
There will be no actual physical home and all sensors and controllers will be simulated . <end>
However , the simulated environment will be realistic and adhere to the physical properties and constraints of an actual home and to real sensors and controllers . <end>
Major changes to this document ( e . g . , changes in requirements ) must be approved by the Director of the DigitalHomeOwner Division . <end>
Although the system to be developed is a “ proof of concept ” system intended to help Homeowner Inc . <end>
To make marketing and development decisions , the following sections describe operational environment concerns and constraints . <end>
Some of them are related to issues of long - term production and marketing of a DigitalHome product . <end>
The home system shall require an Internet Service Provider ( ISP ) . <end>
The Internet Service Provider should be widely available ( cable modem , high speed DSL ) , such as Bright House or Bellsouth FastAccess . <end>
A DigitalHome System shall have the capability to establish an individual home web server hosted on a home computer . <end>
The home web server will provide interaction with and control of the DigitalHome elements . <end>
The home web server will provide storage of DigitalHome plans and data . <end>
The home web server will provide ability to establish and maintain DigitalHome User Accounts . <end>
The home web server will provide backup service for user account information , user plans and a home database . <end>
The DigitalHome Gateway device shall provide communication with all the DigitalHome devices and shall connect with a broadband Internet connection . <end>
The Gateway shall contain an RF Module , which shall send and receive wireless communications between the Gateway and the other DigitalHome devices ( sensors and controllers ) . <end>
The Gateway device shall operate up to a 1000 - foot range for indoor transmission . <end>
The system shall include digital programmable thermostats , which shall be used to monitor and regulate the temperature of an enclosed space . <end>
The thermostat shall provide a reading of the current temperature in the space where the thermostat is located . <end>

The controller part of thermostat shall provides a “ set point ” temperature that is used to control the flow of heat energy ( by switching heating or cooling devices on or off as needed ) to achieve the set point temperature . <end>
The sensor part of the thermostat has a sensitivity range between 14ºF and 104ºF ( - 10ºC and 40ºC ) . <end>
The system shall include digital programmable humidistats , which shall be used to monitor and regulate the humidity of an enclosed space . <end>
The humidistat shall provide a reading of the current humidity in the space where the humidistat is located . <end>
The humidistat shall provide a “ set point ” humidity that is used to control humidifiers and dehumidifiers achieve the set point humidity . <end>
The system shall include magnetic alarm contact switches which shall be used to monitor entry through a door or window when the switch is active . <end>
The system shall include security sound and light alarms , which can be activated when DigitalHome senses a security breach from a magnetic contact . <end>
The system shall include digital programmable power switches which shall be used to monitor the current state of an appliance ( e . g . , a coffee maker is off or on ) . <end>
The system shall be able to use a power switch to change the state of the appliance ( e . g . , from “ off ” to “ on ” ) . <end>
This section provides a description of the functional requirements . <end>
There is a DigitalHome Use Case Model in the Appendix , which provides an overview of the system functionality and shows the relationhips between the DigitalHome System entity . <end>
The DigitalHome System shall allow a web - ready computer , cell phone or PDA to control a home ' s temperature , humidity , lights , security , and the state of small appliances . <end>
The communication center of the DigitalHome system shall be a DigitalHome home web server , through which a user shall be able to monitor and control home devices and systems . <end>

Each DigitalHome shall contain a master control device ( the DigitalHome Gateway Device ) that connects to the home ’ s broadband Internet connection , and uses wireless communication to send and receive communication between the DigitalHome system and the home devices and systems . <end>

The DigitalHome shall be equipped with various environmental controllers and sensors ( temperature controller - sensors : thermostats , humidity controller - sensors : humidistats , contact sensors , security sound and light alarms , and power switches ) . <end>
Using wireless communication , sensor values can be read and saved in the home database . <end>
Controller values can be sent to controllers to change the DigitalHome environment . <end>
The DigitalHome programmable thermostat shall allow a user to monitor and control a home ’ s temperature from any location , using a web ready computer , cell phone , or PDA . <end>
A DigitalHome user shall be able to read the temperature at a thermostat position . <end>
A DigitalHome user shall be able to set the thermostat temperatures to between 60 °F and 80 °F , inclusive , at one degree increments . <end>
Up to eight thermostats shall be placed in rooms throughout the home . <end>
The thermostats may be controlled individually or collectively , so that temperature can be controlled at different levels in different home spaces . <end>
A single thermostat shall be placed in an enclosed space ( e . g . , a room in the house ) for which the air temperature is to be controlled . <end>
For each thermostat , up to twenty - four one hour settings per day for every day of the week can be scheduled . <end>

If a thermostat device allows a user to make a manual temperature setting , the setting shall remain in effect until the end of the planned or default time period , at which time the planned or default setting will be used for the next time period . <end>
A thermostat unit shall communicate , through wireless signals , with the master control unit . <end>
The system shall support Fahrenheit and Celsius temperature values . <end>
The system shall be compatible with a centralized HVAC ( Heating , Ventilation and Air Conditioning ) systems : gas , oil , electricity , solar , or a combination of two or more . <end>
The system shall adhere to the standards , policies and procedures of the American Society of Heating , Refrigerating and Air - Conditioning Engineers [ ASHRAE 2010 ] . <end>
The DigitalHome programmable humidistat shall allow a user to monitor and control a home ’ s humidity from any location , using a web ready computer , cell phone , or PDA . <end>
A DigitalHome user shall be able to read the humidity at a humidistat position . <end>
A DigitalHome user shall be able to set the humidity level for a humidistat , from 30 % to 60 % , inclusive a 1 % increments . <end>
Up to eight humidistats shall be placed in rooms throughout the home . <end>
A single humidistat shall be placed in an enclosed space ( e . g . , a room in the house ) for which the humidity is to be controlled . <end>

If a humdistat device allows a user to make a manual temperature setting , the setting shall remain in effect until the end of the planned or default time period , at which time the planned or default setting will be used for the next time period . <end>
For each humidistat , up to twenty - four one hour settings per day for every day of the week can be scheduled . <end>
A DigitalHome system shall use wireless signals to communicate , through the master control unit , with the humidistats . <end>
The DigitalHome security system consists of contact sensors and a set security alarms . <end>
A DigitalHome system shall be able to manage up to fifty door and window contact sensors . <end>
A DigitalHome system shall be able to activate both light and sound alarms : one sound alarm and one light alarm subsystem , with multiple lights . <end>
When a security breach occurs and a contact sensor is set OPEN , the alarm system shall be activated . <end>
The DigitalHome programmable Appliance Manager shall provide for management of a home ’ s small appliances , including lighting units , by allowing a user to turn them on or off as desired . <end>
The Appliance Manager shall be able to manage up to one hundred 115 volt , 10 amp power switches . <end>
The system shall be able to provide information about the state of a power switch ( OFF or ON ) , indicating the whether an appliance connected to the power switch is OFF or ON . <end>
The system shall be able to change the state of a power switch ( OFF to ON , or ON to OFF ) , in turn changing the state of an appliance connected to the power switch . <end>

If a user changes the state of power switch device manually , the device shall remain in that state until the end of the planned or default time period , at which time the planned or default setting will be used for the next time period . <end>

DigitalHome Planner shall provide a user with the capability to direct the system to set various preset home parameters ( temperature , humidity , security contacts , and on / off appliance / light status ) for certain time periods . <end>

For a given month and year , a user shall be able to create or modify a month plan that specifies for each day , for up to four daily time periods , the environmental parameter settings ( temperature , humidity , contact sensors and power switches ) . <end>
A user shall be able to override planned parameter values , through the DigitalHome website , or if available , through manual switches on household devices <end>
For a given month and year , in the past two years , DigitalHome shall be able to provide a report on the management and control of the home . <end>
The month report shall contain daily average , maximum ( with time ) and minimum ( with time ) values of temperature and humidity for each thermostat and humidistat , respectively . <end>
The month report shall provide the day and time for which any security breaches occurred , that is , when the security alarms were activated . <end>
The month report shall provide a section that indicates the periods of time when the DigitalHome System was not in operation . <end>
Displays of environmental conditions ( temperature , humidity , contact sensors and power switches ) shall be updated at least every two seconds . <end>
Sensor ( temperature , humidity , contact sensor , power state ) shall have a minimum data acquisition rate of 10 Hz . <end>
An environmental sensor or controller device shall have to be within 1000 feet of the master control device , in order to be in communication with the system . <end>
The DigitalHome System must be highly reliable with no more than 1 failure per 10 , 000 hours of operation . <end>
The Digital Home System shall incorporate backup and recovery mechanisms . <end>

The DigitalHome System will backup all system data ( configuration , default parameter settings , planning , and usage data ) on a daily basis , with the backup time set by the DigitalHome Technician at system set up . <end>

If the DigitalHome System fails ( due to power loss , loss of internet access , or other software or hardware failure ) , the system recovery mechanism shall restore system data ( configuration , default parameter settings , planning , and usage data ) from the most recent backup . <end>
All DigitalHome operations shall incorporate exception handling so that the system responds to a user with a clear , descriptive message when an error or an exceptional condition occurs . <end>
Although there are no specific safety requirements , high system reliability is important to insure there are no system failures in carrying out user requests . <end>

Such failures might affect the safety of home dwellers ( e . g . , security breaches , inadequate lighting in dark spaces , inappropriate temperature and humidity for people who are in ill - health , or powering certain appliances when young children are present ) . <end>
Upon installation , a DigitalHome user account shall be established . <end>
The DigitalHome web system shall provide for authentication and information encryption through a recognized reliable and effective security technology , such as Transport Layer Security . <end>
Log in to an account shall require entry of an account name and a password . <end>
The development of the DigitalHome system shall use methods and techniques such as the following to support system maintenance . <end>

Although the product produced under this document will be a “ prototype ” version , all modules and components of this prototype version shall be designed and implemented in such a manner that it may be incorporated in a fully specified commercial version of the DigitalHome System . <end>

All system documents ( Software Requirements Specification , Architectural Design Specification , Module Detailed Design , Module Source Code , and all Test Plans ) shall be up - to - date , use the Homeowner document format [ HO2305 ] and reside in the HomeOwner Document Archive at completion of the project . <end>
HomeOwner has designated object - oriented development , using UML 2 . 0 , as the preferred method for development of software for HomeOwner products . <end>
Exceptions to this rule must be approved by the CIO . <end>
